brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a potential issue in JUnit testing where both parent and child classes in a test hierarchy are annotated with @RunWith. This can lead to unexpected testing behavior.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'runWithAnnotationExistsInParent' checks for each class in the project. If a class is annotated with '@RunWith', it then checks for each parent class in the class's hierarchy. If a parent class is also annotated with '@RunWith', it asserts that the parent class should not be annotated with '@RunWith'. If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating that both the parent and child classes are annotated with '@RunWith', which can lead to unexpected testing behavior.
PRE_model_validation: The rule 'runWithAnnotationExistsInParent' is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses the built-in functions 'getClasses', 'hasAnnotation', 'getFamily', 'getFQN', and 'msg', which are all part of the RSL language. The rule does not introduce any new built-in functions.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/junit-5-runwith
Summary: This page explains the use of @RunWith annotation in JUnit and its potential issues. It also discusses the transition from JUnit 4 to JUnit 5 and how the @RunWith annotation has been replaced by @ExtendWith in JUnit 5.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21304426/what-does-junits-runwith-do
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses the purpose of the @RunWith annotation in JUnit and how it can affect the execution of tests. It also mentions potential issues when using this annotation incorrectly.
